title: Ayurvedic Herbs and Tips for a Smoother Cycle
author: MAPI Team
description: Ayurvedic herbs can help rebalance the downward flow of menstruation and ease menstrual discomfort. Discover Ayurvedic tips for a smoother cycle.
cleaned_text: In these modern times, over-working, poor diets, and extra stress have become the norm. Unfortunately, according to Ayurveda, these are the very variables that can knock your cycle out of balance. Traditional Ayurvedic herbal formulas offer great support for a smoother cycle and balancing Apana Vata—a [subdosha of Vata](https://mapi.com/blogs/articles/understanding-the-5-subdoshas-of-vata) responsible for the normal, downward flow of menstruation and elimination. The following specific Ayurvedic herbs and lifestyle practices can also help remove digestive impurities (ama) and promote hormone balance for a smoother cycle. Smooth cycle: Ayurvedic herbs for hormone balance The herbs and minerals in [Smooth Cycle](https://www.mapi.com/products/smooth-cycle) help nourish and balance your hormones, emotions, mind, liver, blood, hemoglobin, digestion, bones and fertility. Combined in precise proportions and prepared properly, these herbs aid the bioavailability and assimilation of vital nutrients. This formulation of herbs creates a synergy—where the collective benefit is much greater than that of isolated, individual herbs. This synergistic power is an important goal in Maharishi Ayurveda formulations. The specific herbs in Smooth Cycle are: - Asoka Tree, Lodh Tree and Sacred Fig — three of the most famous [herbs for feminine health](https://mapi.com/collections/womens-health). They help balance the menstrual flow (Apana Vata), hormones and emotions ( [Sadhaka Pitta](https://mapi.com/blogs/articles/understanding-the-5-subdoshas-of-pitta)). - Mango Seed, Lodh Tree, Sacred Fig, Sandalwood and Waterlily promote the normal quantity of blood flow. - Iron (Ferri Sulphuratum) and Mineral Pitch help maintain the proper level of hemoglobin. Preparing for an easier cycle Because of the variety of issues and the involvement of so many subdoshas, it is always good to see an Ayurvedic expert to tailor a program to your specific needs. However, here are traditional guidelines for a woman's monthly cycle: - Detox: "Keep your body [ama-free](https://mapi.com/blogs/articles/removing-ama)," is the first and most important recommendation. Ama results from improper diet, poor digestion and inefficient elimination. To eliminate toxins from your diet, avoid stimulants such as alcohol, cigarettes and coffee. Stay away from fast food, junk food, leftovers and preservatives. Consume a variety of fresh fruits and vegetables, grains, lentils, milk, [lassi](https://www.mapi.com/blogs/recipes/digestive-lassi) and fresh cheese such as [paneer](https://mapi.com/blogs/recipes/fresh-paneer-recipe) and ricotta. These fresh and nourishing foods will not only keep your body healthier, but will also be easier on your digestive system. - Rest: Take it easy during your monthly cycle. Assist your body in purifying. The process will be smoother and more comfortable. Try to rest for at least one day. Turn inward, and try to avoid things that make you upset or worried. Do something you enjoy. Eat light, warm, preferably liquid [foods that pacify Vata](https://www.mapi.com/blogs/articles/understanding-vata-dosha). Your digestive fire is weaker during this time, so try not to strain it with heavy foods. Avoid exercise more strenuous than a short walk. Skip your daily massage during the days of your period. In Maharishi Ayurveda we refer to this time of the month as "resting" rather than the "monthly cycle" or "period." Name and form—take some time off. - Plan: Prepare ahead. A balanced routine during the entire month will reward you with less discomfort. Follow a [balanced daily routine](https://mapi.com/blogs/articles/dinacharya-a-routine-to-align-our-natural-rhythm), including going to bed before 10:00 p.m. and getting up at 6:00 a.m. Eat your meals around the same time every day. - Exercise: Regular moderate exercise improves circulation and metabolism, which are essential for the purification process. Practice deep and easy breathing for increased vitality. - Abhyanga: Start the day with a [full-body massage](https://www.mapi.com/blogs/articles/5-surprising-benefits-of-abhyanga)with [Youthful Skin Massage Oil for Women](https://www.mapi.com/products/youthful-skin-massage-oil-for-women-net-4-fl-oz-118-ml). - Digestion: Pay attention to your elimination. If you don't have a bowel movement every day, include cooked prunes and figs in your diet. Cook them with a [stewed apple](https://mapi.com/blogs/recipes/stewed-apples-cooked-apples-with-cloves)every morning. Consume more fresh papaya, pomegranate and pineapple to balance hormones and open up the channels of the physiology. Reduce eggplant, bananas, bell peppers, tomatoes and big beans in your diet, because they are considered harder to digest and can cause ama build-up. Lifestyle matters: regular maintenance for a smoother cycle Three key principles to long-term menstrual balance and wellness in Ayurveda can be broadly summed up in three lifestyle tactics: - Reducing toxins (ama) - Balancing/strengthening digestion (agni) - Significantly lowering stress Each of these choices has the power to gradually, naturally support and restore balance in mind and body. These [lifestyle choices](https://www.mapi.com/ayurvedic-knowledge/stress/ayurvedic-tips-for-beating-everyday-stress.html) include changes to diet; stress reduction practices like yoga, exercise and meditation; and traditional Ayurvedic herbals, to name just a few. Digestion is a central long-term, priority focus of Ayurveda. Great emphasis is placed on keeping digestion (agni) balanced. In this sense, "balance" means functioning at its absolute optimum. That's because digestion is the engine of transformation and assimilation. This transformation "engine" isn't found just in the stomach—it's also found in every cell in the body. It is an extremely intelligent engine, too. It transforms and metabolizes food nutrients and food intelligence into you, and selects out that which isn't useful to the body and mind. Depending on the strength of agni, the "transformation engine," either toxins (ama) or [ojas](https://www.mapi.com/blogs/articles/restoring-depleted-ojas) (the beneficial biochemical of balance) will be created. Ojas is the finest and most-valued by-product of digestion in ayurveda, supporting immunity, happiness, the feeling of connectivity (union or yoga) and emotional stability. Additional Ayurvedic herbals are very helpful for not only restoring hormone health and a smoother cycle—but also whole-body wellness.
